case_vignette: A 49-year-old man comes to the physician because of tender, red nodules that appeared on his chest 3 days ago! Three weeks ago, he had similar symptoms in his right lower limb and another episode in his left foot; both episodes resolved spontaneously! He also has diarrhea and has had a poor appetite for 1 month! He has a history of dry cough and joint pain, for which he takes albuterol and aspirin as needed! He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 15 years! He does not drink alcohol! Physical examination shows a linear, erythematous lesion on the right anterior chest wall, through which a cord-like structure can be palpated! The lungs are clear to auscultation! The abdomen is soft, nontender, and non-distended! Examination of the legs is normal! An ultrasound of the legs shows no abnormalities!
question: Which  is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis of the underlying condition?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have tender, red nodules on my chest that appeared 3 days ago.
Have you experienced similar symptoms in the past?
Yes, three weeks ago I had similar symptoms in my right lower limb and another episode in my left foot; both episodes resolved spontaneously.
Do you have any underlying medical conditions like Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, or arthritis?
I have a history of dry cough and joint pain.
Have any of your family members experienced similar skin issues or any autoimmune diseases?
I don't know, I haven't mentioned anything about my family's medical history.
Do the nodules you have on your chest feel warm to the touch, and have any of them developed a head or begun draining?
The nodules are tender and red, but I haven't mentioned whether they feel warm or have developed a head or begun draining.
Final Diagnosis: Erythema Nodosum.

Additionally, the patient has been experiencing diarrhea and a poor appetite for the last month. The patient also confirms experiencing joint pain. There are no known chronic inflammatory or gastrointestinal conditions reported by the patient. There has been no recent initiation of new medications or therapies. trial_4.summarized_frq: The most appropriate next step in diagnosis is to refer the patient to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and consider potential inflammatory bowel disease, as the combination of skin, joint, and gastrointestinal symptoms could be suggestive of this condition. Additionally, consider ordering a colonoscopy and appropriate laboratory tests like CRP, ESR, and fecal calprotectin.
